items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but steady at our Chapel Wood observation borehole in the Leckhampstead area following recent rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may continue to be affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect groundwater levels to remain high over the next few weeks and levels remain sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground. Levels may start to increase again if we receive further rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 15/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but steady  at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm near Great Shefford in response to the winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level at which communities may continue to be affected by flooding from groundwater. Groundwater levels are currently steady, but could rise further following recent rainfall. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels and may start to rise again if we receive further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 15/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Sherborne St John area
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Tile Barn Farm borehole near the Sherborne St John area as a result of persistent rainfall and saturated grounds. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few days. We expect levels to remain high over the next few days and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by  12/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is very high, close to the surface, and slowly rising at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with springs affecting fields and water on roads including Stoughton main road and large volumes of water on the road from East Marden. Groundwater will affect a small number of properties close to the village green Stoughton. Groundwater could affect basements or be near the ground floor of properties in Walderton too. Brief bands of rain Saturday morning and evening will increase surface water on roads. Rain is possible Sunday too, but locations of rainfall are uncertain. Between 10-20mm of rain is possible. If the maximum rainfall amounts occur, groundwater could continue rising through to 15/03/2024 at the Compton borehole. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall throughout March and possibly April. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 12/03/2024

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over all high tides from Sunday morning until Wednesday afternoon.
High water at Ilfracombe is at 05:45 on Sunday morning and 18:15 on Sunday evening. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 3 easterly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.5m are forecast on Sunday morning. Force 2 North Westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.2m are forecast on Sunday evening.
These conditions are likely to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates daily. Detailed tidal information: The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Sunday morning is 5.18 mAOD, this is 0.28 metres above astronomical tide level. The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Sunday evening is 5.13 mAOD, this is 0.27 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued for Sunday morning's tide 10/03/24 at 6:41 AM. We are expecting a level of approximately 2.45 mAOD in the harbour with Southerly force 2 winds . Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. The next few days will see the third highest spring tides of the year which with a surge may result in high water levels. We are expecting higher than normal tides up to and including the morning tide of the 14th of March. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of high tides and rising river levels flooding is expected. Conditions may apply either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks:- Newport 7.2m to 7.3m 07:00am Sunday morning and 7.2m to 7.3m 19:30pm Sunday afternoon, 10/03/24
Avonmouth Portbury 7.5m to 7.6m 07:15am Sunday morning and 7.5m to 7.6m 19:30pm Sunday afternoon, 10/03/24
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please stay away from large waves as they are dangerous.  
This message will be updated  by 9am on 10/03/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest tomorrow morning at 11:15 AM on 10/03/2024.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss at 11:15 AM on 10/03/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 4 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 10/03/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 02:30AM and 06:30AM tomorrow, 10/03/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. Areas most likely to be affected are the Port of Sunderland Harbour and surrounding areas, including riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
High tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, 10/03/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 03:00AM and 06:00AM, 10/03/2024 with wave overtopping possible around this time. Areas most likely to be affected are Seaburn Lower Promenade, Whitley Sands Promenade, Seaham Harbour and Docks and Hendon Promenade.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued as we can expect waves and spray overtopping on the coast throughout the next few days, as a result of a period of spring tides. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely for both of Sundays 10/03/2024 high tides from 5am to 7:30am and 4:30pm to 8pm, as well as both tides on Monday and the evening high tides Tuesday and Wednesday.   Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads in the Kilnsea and Spurn Road areas. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the coming days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10am on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected. Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. 

The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level of 3.95mAODN at 6.30 am, on Sunday 10 March 2024, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). 

The following tide on Sunday evening at 18.30 pm is currently forecast above the Flood Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. 

We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10 am tomorrow, Sunday 10 March 2024.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 6:45 AM on 10/03/2024.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.66 mAODN atÂ which is 0.31 m above tide tables, with southerlyÂ force 1 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) We are expecting higher than normal astronomical tides over the next 4 days due to spring tides and as a result we may issue further alerts.

We will be closing locks and flood gates in the area and we will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of high tides. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow. The first high tide is due at 3:30am and levels are due to peak at between 4.8 to 5.0 mAOD. The second high tide time is 3:34pm and the peak will reach between 5.0 to 5.3 mAOD. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 10/03/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon Estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tides from Sunday morning until Wednesday. High water on Sunday morning at Plymouth is at 5:30am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 2 northerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 300mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.87 mAOD, this is 0.3 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast tomorrow morning at 11:00 AM on 10/03/2024.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible between 9:00 AM and 1:00 PM on 10/03/2024.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next four days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Saturday evening's tide at 23:00 on 09/03/2024 is higher than normal due to high astronomical tides, with unsettled weather and light South Easterly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.26 m. The total forecast tide is 6.13 metres Chart Datum (3.08 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Sunday morning's tide at 11:15 on 10/03/2024 is forecast to be 3.06 mAOD. Tides are forecast to be about 10cm higher on Sunday evening and Monday 11/03/2024, but still accompanied by light winds and small waves. Minimal flood impacts, similar to Saturday evening, could be possible each high water until Thursday (14/03/2024). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 19:00 on 10/03/2024.

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.description: River Teign area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Saturday evening and throughout Sunday.
Persistent rainfall in the River Teign catchment today and overnight will lead to rising river levels.
Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 8pm today, with rivers reaching their highest levels between 7am and 8am tomorrow morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and will issue further flood warning if required. This message will be updated on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:

items.description: River Frome in Herefordshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Bishops Frome, Yarkhill and Bromyard river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight 09/03/2024.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Frome from Bromyard to Hereford. Other locations that may be affected include Bishops Frome and Yarkhill.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise on the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull with tides over the next few days. This could cause periodic flooding of low lying land in the central River Hull area including around Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell.  Rainfall is forecast overnight tonight and Sunday morning (10/03/2024).  We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/03/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message: Flows in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge are high and increasing. In the last hour, 0.65mm of rain has fallen at Portswood. Whilst not a large total, it follows weeks of prolonged wet weather. High tide at Southampton is at 22:15 today. Tide levels are normal for a spring tide and are forecast at 4.93 mCD (2.19 mAOD) at Southampton. Tomorrow's tide at 10:15 is 4.94 mCD (2.2 mAOD). For 2 hours either side of high tide, the river will come out of bank affecting the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Parts of Riverside Park will be flooded. Levels will be very high at Gaters Mill. Further rain will affect the area over the next 24 hours with 10mm widespread, and up to 15-20mm in isolated showers. As river flows will continue to increase there is a risk of flooding on every high tide over the next two days. To help lower water levels we have operated the sluices at Woodmill. We recommend closing the defence gates around the pub at least an hour before and after high tide. This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on 10/03/2024.
